title: WHATWG Console Workstream-relevant MDN issues
description: Issue filed on MDN Web Docs related to pages attached to technologies developed by WHATWG Console Workstream

items.content_html:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/console/timeLog

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

parameters

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

incomplete: console.timeLog() accepts multiple parameters, like console.log(). at least in firefox and node.js

What did you expect to see?

information about which console timers' functions accept multiple parameters, if any besides timeLog

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

https://nodejs.org/api/console.html#consoletimeloglabel-data

Do you have anything more you want to share?

456 is logged with these js statements:

console.time('123'); console.timeLog('123', 456); console.timeEnd('123');

firefox:

console.time('123'); console.timeLog('123', 456); console.timeEnd('123');
123: 1ms 456
123: 1ms - timer ended
undefined

node:

> console.time('123'); console.timeLog('123', 456); console.timeEnd('123');
123: 0.144ms 456
123: 1.434ms
undefined

MDN metadata

items.title: [console] console.timeLog() acceps multiple parameters

items.content_html:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/console/trace

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

console.trace()

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

Add a note that some browsers also include the source of the call stack from async events.
I suggest this as it would prevent confusion when developers add console.trace()'s to points reached through async events.
My example of confusion was in recursive setTimeout as described in stack overflow

and also in google

Here is an example from recursive setTimeout()...

loop.js:26 console.trace
loop	@	loop.js:26
(anonymous)	@	loop.js:21
Promise.then (async)		
loop	@	loop.js:18
(anonymous)	@	loop.js:21
Promise.then (async)		
loop	@	loop.js:18
(anonymous)	@	loop.js:21

as generated from this code:

export function loop()
{
    console.log('enter loop');
    let myPromise = new Promise((resolve,reject)=>
    {
        if (window.counter > 100)
        {
            return;
        }
        window.counter = window.counter+1;

        setTimeout(()=>
        {
            resolve("done");
        },500);
    });

    myPromise.then((msg)=>
    {

        loop();

    })
    console.log('exit loop');
    console.log('---call stack start---')
    console.trace();
    console.log('--- call stack done---');

}

What did you expect to see?

I think a short note is all that is needed such as
'Note, that in some browsers, console.trace() may also include the sequence of calls and asynchronouse events that lead to the current console.trace() which are not not on the call stack to help identify the origin of the current event evaluation loop.'

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

stack overflow
google

Do you have anything more you want to share?

no

MDN metadata

Page report details

items.title: [console] trace() from chrome and firefox also include async sources, would help to note this as it confused me.

items.content_html:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/console/group

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Examples

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The examples are missing illustrations of how the label parameter to console.group() can and should be used.

What did you expect to see?

Examples illustrating the effects of using a label, possibly with advice on intended use.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

items.content_html:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Console

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The section "Using string substitutions" mentions that %i and %d allow number formatting, and gives a single example, but this example does not fully explain how this is used. In addition to that, in my testing, it appears that Chrome ignores the formatting and prints out the number with %i, %d, and %f.

Specific section or headline?

Under "Using string substitutions" and under "Browser Compatibility"

What did you expect to see?

I expected to see either a description, or a link to a page with a description, on how one may use the number formatting. It isn't quite straightforward from what is written here. In addition to this, I expected to see Browser Compatibility make some mention that the formatting is ignored on Chrome.

Did you test this? If so, how?

I tested out number formatting, and (at least on chrome) the logging (log, info, warn, and error) appears to ignore number formatting. The "Browser Compatibility" section has no mention of this substitution string formatting issue.

  • GitHub URL: https://github.com/mdn/content/blob/main/files/en-us/web/api/console/index.html

items.title: [console] Issue with "console", how does number formatting work? Number formatting doesn't work on Chrome.
